perturbation.original_text: This amendment to Section 2 (titled "Term"), Part B of the Co-Branding Agreement is made effective December 9, 1996 by and between PC Quote, Inc. (hereinafter referred to as "PCQ") and A.B. Watley, Inc. (hereinafter referred to as "ABW"), who are also the parties contracted in the aforementioned Co-Branding Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: This amendment to Section 2 (titled "Term"), Part B of the Co-Branding Agreement is made effective December 9, 1996 by and between PC Quote, Inc. (hereinafter referred to as "PCQ") and A.B. Watley, Inc. (hereinafter referred to as "Watley"), who are also the parties contracted in the aforementioned Co-Branding Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'ABW' to 'Watley' creates confusion. 'ABW' is already defined and using 'Watley' introduces an undefined and potentially different term for the same party, creating uncertainty in later sections referring to either.

perturbation.original_text: This Amendment shall apply to said PCQ and ABW and all of their subsidiaries and related companies.
perturbation.changed_text: This Amendment shall apply to said PCQ and Watley and all of their affiliates and related companies.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'ABW' to 'Watley' (as done previously) and 'subsidiaries' to 'affiliates' adds to confusion. Are 'Watley' and 'ABW' the same? Are 'subsidiaries' and 'affiliates' equivalent for the purposes of this agreement? The uncertainty makes it difficult to enforce the terms concerning related entities.

perturbation.original_text: AGREED TO BY: /s/ Steven Malin /s/ Howard Meltzer - -------------------------- --------------------------------- A.B. Watley, Inc. PC Quote, Inc.
perturbation.changed_text: AGREED TO BY: /s/ Steven Malin /s/ Howard Meltzer - -------------------------- --------------------------------- Watley, Inc. PC Quote, Inc.
perturbation.explanation: Referencing Watley, Inc. in the signature block further solidifies the inconsistency started previously. The contract now inconsistently uses both 'A.B. Watley, Inc.' and 'Watley, Inc.' to refer to a contracting party. This introduces doubt about whether the document refers to the same entity and whether it is binding upon the correct entity.
